model.hed: Best Hotels and Resorts in Jordan: 2012
model.dek: Hotels and resorts in Jordan on Cond√© Nast Traveler's 2012 Gold List: The World's Best Places to Stay

items.name: Four Seasons Hotel Amman
items.description: Atop the highest of Amman's seven hills, near the Shmeisani financial district, this ten-year-old white limestone building "makes for a wonderful respite after a day touring the sights." Design fuses Greek- and Roman-style columns with Jordanian marble and stone--"it's such a beautiful hotel." Rooms in purple and gold or blue come with plenty of wood detail. "Request one with spectacular city views‚Äîothers overlook a freeway." The service is "typical Four Seasons, with excellent concierges." Vivace's Italian menu includes seafood linguine.

items.name: Kempinski Hotel Aqaba
items.description: With its modern curves, smiling staff, and swimming pools set within a seaside bamboo forest, the Kempinski looks like nothing else in Aqaba, a resort town better known for indifferent service and faux Arabian palaces. White textiles, leather couches, chrome lamps, and white floors make the already spacious rooms seem larger and highlight panoramic views of the Egyptian and Israeli coastline (unfortunately, you can also see directly into the glass-walled bathroom, despite the translucent shade). A 15-minute drive from Aqaba‚Äôs main snorkeling and diving beaches, the Kempinski, along with its imported white sand beach and floating water sports dock, is sandwiched between another resort and a still-to-be-filled coastal plot, and there‚Äôs no avoiding the sight of container ships off-loading in the port. Still, the strikingly futuristic rooms, excellent fish restaurant, seaside infinity lap pool, and Zen terrace of daybeds and sun loungers‚Äînot to mention the complimentary minibar‚Äîare sure to keep the Kempinski popular with business and leisure travelers alike.

items.name: M√∂venpick Resort & Spa Dead Sea, Jordan
items.description: "It‚Äôs like a fantasy land. You enter a different world" upon arrival at this village-style resort filled with olive trees, whose architecture pays homage to old Jerusalem. With the rich mineral Dead Sea at hand and an outdoor heated massage pool, therapeutic pools, and signature salt and black mud wraps and scrubs, the 65,000-square-foot Zara Spa is "truly top-notch." Rooms overlooking the gardens, water, or mountains are "pleasant but rather plain." Note: "It turns into a mob scene on Muslim weekends, when the locals from nearby Amman visit." At Chopsticks, create your own entr√©e, which is then cooked in a Mongolian wok.

items.name: Evason Ma'In Hot Springs
items.description: This 97-room resort, completely transformed from its 300-room predecessor, has one of the most dramatic settings in Jordan: deep in Wadi Zerqa, a gorge filled with palm trees and warm waterfalls originating in hot springs whose therapeutic benefits were famous in the time of Herod. The resort‚Äôs exterior now references the sandstone of traditional Jordanian village houses as well as the pyramidal step design of Nabatean tombs, while dark African woods, coconut fiber rugs, sliding shutters, and pastel-colored bedouin rugs in the rooms and public spaces fuse contemporary Arabian and Asian eco-minimalism. The most compelling reasons to stay here are the sublime Six Senses Spa, which has its own natural cave sauna and waterfall, and the hotel‚Äôs energetic life experiences staff, including a resident geologist who leads hiking or mountain biking expeditions down canyons that descend from 650 feet above to 1,300 feet below sea level and whose mineral-rich rapids feed the Dead Sea. The seemingly isolated location is actually just 20 scenic minutes by car from Jordan‚Äôs cluster of Dead Sea resorts. The atmosphere changes on the Islamic weekend (Thursday and Friday), when smart young things from Amman come to socialize in the Brown Bar.
